TITLE I--EXTENSIONS OF AUTHORITY

SEC. 101. EXTENSION OF AUTHORITIES UNDER TITLE 38, UNITED STATES CODE. Authority To Provide Priority Health Care for Certain Veterans Exposed to Toxic Substances is extended to December 31, 1996. Drug and Alcohol Abuse and Dependence provisions are extended to December 31, 1997. A Pilot Program for Noninstitutional Alternatives to Nursing Home Care is extended to December 31, 1997. Negotiated Interest Rates section is amended by striking out subparagraph (D). Amendments are made to various sections of the title by striking out specific paragraphs and inserting new dates for compliance. Amendments to various sections of the title involve updating compliance dates by replacing specific dates with new ones. SEC. 102. Extension of authorities under other provisions of law. The text chunk discusses amendments to various laws related to services for homeless veterans, extending deadlines and periods for programs such as Community-Based Residential Care and Compensated Work Therapy. The amendments extend deadlines for grants under the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act and Homeless Veterans' Reintegration Projects, with changes to fiscal years and funding allocations. SEC. 103 of the Act ratifies actions taken by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs during a period of expired authority. TITLE II includes codification of housing reporting requirements and changes in their frequency. The annual report required by section 529 of this title shall include a discussion of activities under this chapter, including loans to veterans in the Selected Reserve, interest rates negotiated between lender and veteran, determination of reasonable value by lenders, loans for energy efficiency improvements, and direct loans to Native American veterans. The table of sections in the chapter is amended to include new reporting requirements. The Veterans Home Loan Program Amendments of 1992 are updated by repealing certain reporting requirements. SEC. 202. OTHER REPORT REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must report to Congress by March 1, 1997, on the potential consolidation of three programs related to alcohol and drug abuse, community-based residential care for homeless mentally ill veterans, and a demonstration program. Additionally, a report on the health professional scholarship program is due by March 31, 1997. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to evaluate the health professional scholarship program's effectiveness in recruiting and retaining healthcare personnel for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The study will compare the program's costs and benefits with alternative methods. Additionally, a report on the Enhanced Use Leases program is due to Congress by March 31, 1997. SEC. 203. CONTRACTS FOR UTILITIES, AUDIE L. MURPHY MEMORIAL HOSPITAL. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may enter into contracts for utilities at the Audie L. Murphy Memorial Hospital in San Antonio, Texas, for up to 35 years. Contracts may include construction of a production facility, capital contributions, and a formula to compute costs. Funding for contracts must be provided in advance in appropriations Acts. The Secretary may include additional provisions in a contract to secure utilities and protect US interests, as provided in appropriations Acts.
